title: Between 13 November 2020 and 12 February 2021, will the closing price per barrel of WTI crude oil be higher than the closing price per barrel of Brent crude oil?
preds: ends in two hours and no favorable change
less than a day left and WTI is at $58.33 and decreasing at .63% compared to Brent at 61.20. decreasing at .44%.  https://oilprice.com/oil-price-charts/45
WTI crude oil is $58.33 and there is a 0.58% decrease and Brent crude oil is $61.47 and there is a 0.62% increase, so it seems very unlikely for WTI to exceed Brent crude oil.

Brent crude oil currently sits at 61.42USD/bbl and WTI is at 58.60USD/bbl. Both are extremely close to their previous closing price with WTI currently performing slightly under and Brent performing slightly better. With such little time left and Brent's price rising at a higher rate than WTI's price, it is highly unlikely that WTI will be able to surpass Brent. 
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CO1:COM

Historically, there is almost no precedent for WTI crude oil to be higher than the closing price per barrel of Brent crude oil. Furthermore, it is suspected that Biden may lift economic sanctions on Iran -- of which has negatively impacted Iranian oil exports -- which would increase the supply of oil, decreasing the price of WTI crude as they are considered less flexible than Brent [1].  Additionally, Brent unexpectedly raised the price of their oil to $60 via a 2% increase, further distancing from WTI's price of $56, further reinforcing their lack of competitiveness [2]. [1] https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/052615/what-difference-between-brent-crude-and-west-texas-intermediate.asp
[2] https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/08/oil-markets-brent-crude-futures-us-economy.html EDIT ON 3/30/21 There has been no change in market conditions regarding WTI and Brent. Surprisingly, the Evergreen freighter incident has not negatively affected oil prices. Therefore my chance level shall remain at 5%.

Based on data from investing.com, WTI futures have been priced above Brent futures only 0.5% of the time in the past 10 years. More recently (2020 and 2021 up to Feb 6th), this has been the case for a single trading day (~0.35%). The spread on closing prices is currently sitting at -2.49, with 5 days to go. Over the past 10 years, only 0.3% of the time has there been a 5-day move of more than +2.49 in the spread, when WTI is trading just a few $ below Brent.

Two week check before resolution to question.
There's a 2.66$ difference.
In my recollection WTI has never been above Brent mostly due to the quality of the Crude.
The current split between Brent and WTI is $2.62.  The chance is remove that WTI will make up this split in a little more than a week.
Update for time remaining until end date

Because:
-today price, a few days before the february, 12;
-rational of @incognito
- consensus of others forecasters.
less than a 3 dollar spread two days running.

Oil prices have increased recently, but Brent and WTI have both gone up 3.34%  The split between the two is almost 4 dollars a barrel, which is at a peak for the last six months.  The likelihood of WTI overcome this deficit in a month is not high. Additionally, Brent increased in December 2020 after vaccine approvals occurred.  OPEC decided on 3 December 2020 to limit its previously planned January 2021 production increases, regulating the amount of oil available.  Prices of oil traditionally increase in the winter months because of heating demands.  All of these factors compound driving oil prices up and minimizing extreme fluctuations in the market.

Reading the comments and watching the graph of the spread (useful link here: https://ycharts.com/indicators/brent_wti_spread) the trend WTI < Brent looks very strong.
Last time WTI > Brent happend was september 2 of 2020. However, given the global situation, the oil market is not completely certain and predictible so I think 7% of WTI > Brent happening before 12 february is fair.

now with some base rates:
since	               1988	2000	2010	2015
p(WTI>Brent)	60%	40%	4%	         1% https://www.hellenicshippingnews.com/oil-why-is-brent-more-expensive-than-wti/
Quality of Brent is worse but WTI is competing with shale so local excess capacity? so that balance in market forces will persist over the next 7 weeks.
we are looking to forecast something more anomalous like mafunctions in supply chain, speculation etc.
i think the prob since 2015 is a good indication so inclined to further lower my prob to that base rate. keep an eye out for opec meetings: decisions to break existing supply-restrictions could increase market volatility.
Haven't check historical relation but i guess volatility increases the prob of unexpected moves likes WTI>Brent.
It's unlikely. WTI has been following Brent's price pattern almost exactly.

It seems as though the gap may be slightly closing, so I will keep a closer eye on this one as we move forward. It may be a possibility now that the new strain of COVID is hampering the economy, however, it is also reportedly in the United States now as well.

The main fundamental drivers of the spread between Brent and WTI are:
US crude oil production levels
Crude oil supply and demand balance in the US - i.e. crude oil inventory position in the US vs. the Gulf region
North Sea crude oil operations
Geopolitical issues in the International crude oil market All of these factors indicate any possible increase would be in the price of Brent not in WTI. US demand has been fairly low and seems to remain so for the duration of the pandemic.

Given the time frame of the question, it's unlikely there will be internal or external shocks to this system large enough to shift the price to Brent lowering to cheaper.  Out-side of a run on Brent, or a catastrophic event, any impact and environmentally focused Biden admin will deliver will not be a surprise and as such, already priced in.

The combined effect of lower supply expectations from OPEC+ countries as well as firmer market expectations for a recovery in global oil demand is contributing to higher prices for near-term oil deliveries relative to prices for delivery further in the future. The five-day moving averages for the Oman crude oil 1st–3rd spread approached 50 cents/b in late November, and Brent’s spread settled at -4 cents/b on December 3. The WTI spread also increased, but by less than the other crude oils. The increasing crude oil price spreads reflect both the global oil inventory drawdown since June 2020 as well as expectations for increasing demand and continued stock draws in the coming months. Higher Oman crude oil price spreads, which generally reflect Middle Eastern crude oil exported to Asia, could reflect increasing demand and refinery runs from China, India, or other Asian countries. China’s National Bureau of Statistics reported that crude oil refinery runs in China reached an all-time high of 14.1 million b/d in October. Based on data from India’s Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas, EIA estimates that India’s total petroleum consumption was 4.6 million b/d in October 2020, the most of any month since February.

WTI, now the benchmark in the U.S., still consistently lags behind Brent prices, which remain the benchmark globally. The two prices at this time typically move in tandem, although the small gap closes every once in a while. Outside of a major global geopolitical crisis that would cause a crash in Brent prices that would cause a rush into WTI, it is unlikely that the WTI will surge ahead of Brent in the short-term.  Any changes from a Biden admin are unlikely to have a major impact in the short-term but could be worth watching long-term.

In the past, WTI traded at a premium to Brent. However, due to the Shale Revolution in the early 2000s (in which WTI production increased), the price of WTI declined. It now usually trades at a discount to Brent.
Today WTI is the benchmark for oil prices in the US, but Brent is the global Benchmark. The spread between Brent and WTI changes from time to time due to geopolitics, weather, and regulation. But they typically trade within a similar spread distance from one another. 
Brent is very sensitive to Geopolitics, while WTI is not as sensitive to geopolitics. Two things may influence a difference in the spread: China buying spree for Brent and the current standard of Brent-WTI spread.
Generally, Brent-WTI tends to move in the same way and spikes of high spreads are rare.
These prices seem to be holding steady, so I am going to keep my forecast the same.

The spread has consistently and structurally priced brent higher than WTI. I don't see large structural shifts occurring by February that would change that. Tracking the spread here: https://ycharts.com/indicators/brent_wti_spread#:~:text=Brent%20WTI%20Spread%20is%20at,74.29%25%20from%20one%20year%20ago.

The US shale revolution that began in 2008 - 2009 significantly increased US oil supply, making the price of WTI oil (US-based benchmark) decline below Brent (international benchmark based on oil prices from 15 different oilfields).

Traditionally, WTI oil trades at a discount in comparison to Brent oil. Historically, Brent oil has been pricier.  I predict that this trend will continue, due to the Shale Revolution of the early 2000s. Helpful link w/contextual background information: https://www.dailyfx.com/crude-oil/wti-vs-brent.html
Uncertainty in the US market will keep WTi prices lower by comparison.

On the basis of mean regression over the last 10-15 years, the current western focus on 'green energy', the realisation that economies will not boom overnight in spite of vaccine availability in the coming weeks and the marginal increase in supply agreed by OPEC + (https://reut.rs/3lIcKJi), I see no reason to change my forecast.

Since 29th July 2007, the conditional probability that the WTI crude oil price will exceed the Brent crude oil price in a particular day given that it hasn't exceeded it in the past 70 days is roughly 2/4000 = %0.05. This gives a base probability of %0.05 * 70 = %3.5 to the event. I round this down to %3 and use it as my forecast.
USA's oil demand is down, and with more emphasis on renewable electric sources in the US, foreign demand for oil will favor Brent.

They trade in a very narrow band, save for the futures crisis in May. It has only breached 1.0 a single time in the past four years, so the base rate is under 0.1%.  It could absolutely trend between now and then, but the situation has changed from the last time it was regularly above 1 (2015 and before).
World is awash with oil; winter is not typically the period when oil demand rises much. There is a little risk of OPEC+ agreement collapsing over the next 2 months.

Constraint by the major OPEC aligned production that influences Brent will remain more tightly controlled and limited over that time period than the production that influences WTI, thus eliminating the likelihood that WTI will gain enough momentum to overtake Brent within that time frame.
For that month the economy could raise because the vaccine of the COVID in the first quarter of the 2021

WTI crude is much cheaper recently due to advances in shale revolution in the U.S. In addition, if there are political instabilities, WTI crude fares better than Brent crude. The current COVID-19 and other uncertainties point to this being the case, and there will very likely be a huge divergence between WTI crude and Brent crude, with Brent crude probably increasing in price much higher than WTI crude.

I have watched the prices for years and that never happens. I believe it’s because the Brent contracts are deliverable in a more flexible way and WTI has to be in Cushing, thus worth less. The crowd forecast is 2% because I think some people just don’t understand that. I would do 0.5% on the chance that there is something I’m missing, but this doesn’t appear to allow fractions of a percent.

some overlap, maybe some volatility but not enough to change my mind.
bar changes in this, probability to go down by the tune of 1%point per month or so.

Just looking at prices of Brent and WTI for January delivery, see this Vegas Sun link... https://lasvegassun.com/news/2020/nov/24/closing-prices-for-crude-oil-gold-and-other-commod/ A propos the "spread"... Brent is selling at nearly three dollars per barrel for January delivery than WTI. Draw your own conclusions...

Decreasing WTI / Brent spread (generally) since the Arab Spring is a rough metric to place a base rate around 40%.  Most data required to generate a robust base rate is behind paywalls for fancy charting.  I expect announcements on an Iran 're-deal' and Paris Accords in January may impact US WTI futures as well as limited ability for fracking based oil extraction to remain profitable over the long term at current oil prices (around 40-45 USD/bbl).  Reduced US output relative to international production, increased middle east output, and restrictions on US exploration / drilling drive the increased probability of a change.

The current price of Brent crude oil is $44.13 per barrel and the current price of WTI is $41.50 per barrel.  Oil prices are contractual per month and these prices reflect the December contract prices.   The price of Brent has been higher than WTI for the past decade.  This price spread peaked to about $20 in the beginning of 2013.  While the price of Brent has outpaced WTI for a decade, this gap has been closing and is currently less than $3 per barrel.  The futures for Brent are $44.46 per barrel in February 2021.  The futures for WTI are $41.92 for February 2021.  This closes the price spread even more, but not to the point where WTI will close higher than Brent.

10% of general market disruption (as in March / April -20) which leads to some closing day with negative spread
+
2% from relative supply changes (50% chance of a relative decline US vs OPEC and 5% that this would feed into market prices in this period)
There's very little possibility of major changes in oil production while the pandemic rages and the U.S. government is in upheaval.

If shale oil in US continues to decline (drilling drops) and the EU continues to push for renewables and less ICE.  The problem it this could happen some time next year vs. this time period.  This question is interesting because it sounds like someone has a option spread on and is concerned about a spike in this time period.  ie Short this option spread.
Historically the WTI is always less than Brent.
mostly brent seems to exceed wti since early 2012

Key things to watch for 
The opec meeting scheduled at the end of the month. The current expectation is they will have to sustain current cuts. 
Libya has already started pumping 1.2 mn barrels (up from 100k in Sept) so thats already in the current spread with the NOC saying that these levels may not be sustainable. Things are a bit more stable on the US side with production being range bound at under 11mn bpd. Demand is not expected to recover as the rigs steadily go up Risks to this Estimate
Opec members unable to reach an agreement on the level of cuts.(Low as MBS has been pretty effective in holding members to their agreed levels of production cuts.) 
A volume war between Russia and Saudi Arabia (Looks low as Russia seems to be in agreement about not increasing production this time around) The current Opec production cut levels are at 7.7mn bpd with 2mn bpd of production easing expected in January( which may not happen now). As of now Russia looks to be onboard with continuing the current levels of production cuts. Russia produces 9.9mn bpd.

According to oilprice.com Brent has consistently outperformed WTI over the last year. They have a direct relationship so even when Brent does fall WTI stays behind. I dont have access to Bloomberg and dont have much other information about oil. I am going to say 30% chance that WTI overtakes Brent between November and February. I will update every month as we get more numbers.

Even though WTI crude is landlocked the pressures on American oil will increase as climate change affects the landscape of this area. I believe micro factors will increase the values (i.e., insurance costs and political shifts to increase green options, etc) which will exert pressures that make the cost of the WTI crude the cheapest it will be for some time. Therefore the price will rise with a slight uptick overtime. On the flip side I feel the north sea Brent crude oil will increase its ability to ship cheaper due to COVID. As shipping costs like commercial real estate will be looking for new markets they will find ways to cuts cost to market, to be more competitive even using smaller lines who want a piece of this piece to stay afloat, or possibility even using drones to load and unload cargo. So I believe the Brent cruse prices will tick down marginally over time. The aggregate will be up for WTI and down for Brent ever so slightly but on a trend so the on-balance will be not huge, but measurable.

20201114 Looking at the historical relationship, I've forecast 0%, albeit the premium of Brent over WTI has shrunk in the last 24 months.  Both are 'sweet' oils albeit WTI has a slightly lower sulphur content. Brent is produced at sea whereas WTI is historically produced in landlocked areas. Fracking in USA has added considerable stock to the WTI futures market even though fracking is not profitable at the $40pb level. The historical price relationship at the turn of the decade was around 10%. IT is currently around 5%.

EIA has recently decreased its oil price forcasts.  Still Brent barrel price is likely to higher than WTI.  Not good news for the old boys who talk shop over breafast at the Cowboy Cafe out in Roswell, NM...
